statements.name: PROC RANK
statements.description: Computes the ranks for one or more numeric variables.
statements.help:
PROC RANK 
            <options>;                   
	ATTRIB   variable-list(s) 
               attribute-list(s);
            
	BY 
               <DESCENDING>
               variable-1
               
		<<DESCENDING>variable-2  ...>
		<NOTSORTED>;
            
	FORMAT 
               variable-1
               < ...variable-n>
               <format>
               <DEFAULT=default-format>;
            
	LABEL 
               variable-1=label-1< ...variable-n=label-n>;
            
	VAR 
               data-set-variables(s);
            
	RANKS 
               new-variables(s);
            
	WHERE 
               where-expression-1
		
               <logical-operator where-expression-n>;

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies the input SAS data set.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: reverses the direction of the ranks.

arguments.name: FRACTION
arguments.description: computes fractional ranks by dividing each rank by the number of observations having nonmissing values of the ranking variable.

arguments.name: GROUPS=
arguments.description: assigns group values ranging from 0 to number-of-groups minus 1.

arguments.name: NORMAL=
arguments.description: computes normal scores from the ranks.

arguments.name: NPLUS1
arguments.description: computes fractional ranks by dividing each rank by the denominator n+1.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: names the output data set.

arguments.name: PRESERVERAWBYVALUES
arguments.description: preserves raw values of all BY variables.

arguments.name: PERCENT
arguments.description: calculates the percentage of observations with nonmissing values in the rank.

arguments.name: SAVAGE
arguments.description: computes Savage (or exponential) scores from the ranks.

arguments.name: TIES=
arguments.description: specifies how to compute normal scores or ranks for tied data values.

arguments.name: HIGH
arguments.description: assigns the largest of the corresponding ranks (or largest of the normal scores when NORMAL= is specified).

arguments.name: LOW
arguments.description: assigns the smallest of the corresponding ranks (or smallest of the normal scores when NORMAL= is specified).

arguments.name: MEAN
arguments.description: assigns the mean of the corresponding rank (or mean of the normal scores when NORMAL= is specified).

arguments.name: DENSE
arguments.description: computes scores and ranks by treating tied values as a single-order statistic. For the default method, ranks are consecutive integers that begin with the number one and end with the number of unique, nonmissing values of the variable that is being ranked. Tied values are assigned the same rank.

statements.name: ATTRIB
statements.description: Associates a format, informat, label, and length with one or more variables.

arguments.name: variable-list
arguments.description: names the variables that you want to associate with the attributes.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: associates a format with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: INFORMAT=
arguments.description: associates an informat with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: associates a label with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the length of variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: TRANSCODE=
arguments.description: specifies whether character variables can be transcoded. Use TRANSCODE=NO to suppress transcoding. Variables with TRANSCODE=NO are not returned.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Produces a separate set of ranks for each BY group.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies the variable that the procedure uses to form BY groups. You can specify more than one variable. If you do not use the NOTSORTED option in the BY statement, then the observations in the data set must either be sorted by all the variables that you specify or be indexed appropriately. Variables in a BY statement are called BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order. The observations are grouped in another way, such as chronological order.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: names one or more variables for SAS to associate with a format. You must specify at least one variable.

arguments.name: format
arguments.description: specifies the format that is listed for writing the values of the variables.

arguments.name: text-string
arguments.description: specifies a label of up to 256 bytes.
removes a label from a variable. Enclose a single blank space in quotation marks to remove an existing label. You can remove labels from multiple variables in a single LABEL statement:

statements.name: WHERE
statements.description: Subsets the input data set by specifying certain conditions that each observation must meet before it is available for processing.

arguments.name: where-expression
arguments.description: is an arithmetic or logical expression that generally consists of a sequence of operands and operators.

arguments.name: logical-operator
arguments.description: can be AND, AND NOT, OR, or OR NOT.

statements.name: RANKS
statements.description: Creates new variables for the rank values.

arguments.name: new-variable
arguments.description: specifies one or more new variables that contain the ranks for the variable(s) listed in the VAR statement. The first variable listed in the RANKS statement contains the ranks for the first variable listed in the VAR statement. The second variable listed in the RANKS statement contains the ranks for the second variable listed in the VAR statement, and so on.

arguments.name: data-set-variable
arguments.description: specifies one or more variables for which ranks are computed.
